channel.copyright: Copyright 2014 The New York Times Company

item.title: Scottish Referendum Could Hinge on the Undecided
item.description: On Twitter and Facebook, and in comments on our website, undecided Scottish readers talked about their concerns over which way to vote on independence.
item.dc:creator: By HANNA INGBER
item.media:description: Scottish partisans at Dumbarton Town Hall in Glasgow, Scotland, on Tuesday. At least 6 percent of potential voters are undecided, according to public opinion polls.

item.title: Chinese Leader Visits Sri Lanka, Chipping Away at India’s Sway
item.description: President Xi Jinping of China arrived in Colombo, the capital, to sign a raft of agreements, after visiting the Maldives to sign agreements there.
item.dc:creator: By DHARISHA BASTIANS and GARDINER HARRIS

item.title: At Buckingham Palace, a Dancing Guard Throws Decorum to the Wind
item.description: The pirouetting guard has enchanted crowds in London with his subversive performance and challenged the notion that such things are simply never done.
item.dc:creator: By ALASTAIR MACAULAY

item.title: House Expected to Vote on Training Syrian Rebels to Fight ISIS
item.description: Republicans will insist on a careful accounting of how the plan fits into a larger strategy to defeat the militant group.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By JONATHAN WEISMAN

item.title: French Prime Minister Wins Parliamentary Vote of Confidence
item.description: The vote had been called by Prime Minister Manuel Valls after a cabinet reshuffle purged leftists who were critical of divisive austerity measures.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: U.S. General to Seek Combat Troops if Airstrikes Can’t Stop ISIS
item.description: Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, told Congress he would recommend deploying limited Special Operations forces if airstrikes were not successful.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By JEREMY W. PETERS
item.media:description: Gen. Martin E. Dempsey, the chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, left, and Defense Secretary Chuck Hagel testified before the Senate Armed Services Committee.

item.title: Temporary Deal Reached on Gaza Reconstruction Material
item.description: Israeli and Palestinian officials reached a temporary accord to move reconstruction material into Gaza, a senior United Nations official said.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA and JODI RUDOREN

item.title: Soldiers Killed in Suicide Attack at U.S. Base in Kabul
item.description: Three soldiers with the American-led coalition were killed Tuesday in the attack on a convoy at the gates of a United States military base, officials said.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: By ROD NORDLAND
item.media:description: NATO soldiers administered first aid after an attack at the gates of a U.S. base in Kabul on Tuesday.

item.title: London Repeats Offer of New Powers if Scotland Votes No
item.description: With two days left before Scots vote in a referendum on independence, the leaders of the three main British political parties sought to avert secession.
item.dc:creator: By ALAN COWELL

item.title: U.N. Sees Need for $1 Billion to Fight Ebola
item.description: With the number of cases doubling in just three weeks, the outbreak risks ballooning into a “humanitarian catastrophe,” a senior official said.
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.media:description: People suspected of having Ebola waited to be admitted to a hospital in Monrovia.

item.title: 800 Million People Still Malnourished, U.N. Says
item.description: Despite a decline in hunger levels, 11.3 percent of the world’s population does not get enough to eat, the United Nations said in a new report.
item.dc:creator: By SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: Ukraine Moves to Strengthen Ties With Europe, and Bolster Truce
item.description: Lawmakers ratified the agreement that was rejected by Ukraine’s former leader, which led to his overthrow in February. They also passed laws meant to strengthen the truce with rebels.
item.dc:creator: By NEIL MacFARQUHAR
item.media:description: Members of the Ukrainian Parliament applauded after they ratified an agreement to deepen economic and political ties with the European Union on Tuesday.

item.title: Setback for India’s Ruling Party
item.description: The Bharatiya Janata Party, coming off a huge victory in May’s parliamentary elections, did poorly in by-elections in three northern states.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR

item.title: Turkey Open to Bids for Refuge by Muslim Brotherhood Exiles
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey said that Muslim Brotherhood leaders could be granted entry to Turkey as long as laws permitted.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: Police Chief Quits Over Child Sex Abuse Scandal in English Town
item.description: Commissioner Shaun Wright said he was retiring after a report found that as many as 1,400 children had been sexually abused in the northern town of Rotherham.
item.dc:creator: By KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:description: Shaun Wright, the police and crime commissioner for South Yorkshire, resigned on Tuesday.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Adam Brookes on China, Secrets and Spies
item.description: Adam Brookes, formerly a longtime China correspondent for the BBC, has written “Night Heron,” a suspenseful page-turner that takes the reader from China’s far west to the streets of Beijing, pulsing with power, danger and intrigue.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL FORSYTHE

item.title: ISIS Draws a Steady Stream of Recruits From Turkey
item.description: A neighborhood in the tourist district of the capital, Ankara, has become a hub for wooing new members of the Islamic State, even as the group holds Turkish hostages.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By CEYLAN YEGINSU
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey, hand raised, and Prime Minister Ahmet Davutoglu, to his right, in August, leaving the Haci Bayram Veli Mosque in Ankara, the capital, where the Islamic State in Iraq and Syria is known to recruit new members.

item.title: Child Mortality Falling, U.N. Says, but Not Fast Enough
item.description: The global mortality rate for children younger than 5 has dropped by nearly half since 1990, but remains high in Africa, the United Nations said.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Turkey Open to Bids for Refuge by Muslim Brotherhood Exiles
item.description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey said that Muslim Brotherhood leaders could be granted entry to Turkey as long as laws permitted.
item.dc:creator: By SEBNEM ARSU

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Final Days for Yangtze’s 140 Million-Year-Old Sturgeon
item.description: A recent survey by the Chinese Academy of Fishery Sciences found that the sturgeon in the Yangtze were now probably sustained solely by artificial breeding and were facing extinction.
item.category: International Union for Conservation of Nature
item.dc:creator: By AUSTIN RAMZY
item.media:description: Artificially bred Chinese sturgeon before their release into the Yangtze River, where for the first time no signs of natural reproduction have been found.

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: What’s Behind Germany’s New Anti-Semitism
item.description: The ugly truth is that much of today’s anti-Semitism originates with people of Muslim background.
item.dc:creator: By JOCHEN BITTNER

item.title: U.N. Investigators Cite Atrocities in Syria
item.description: The “madness” in the civil war includes acts by Islamic extremists as well as by the government of President Bashar al-Assad, the panel said.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE
item.media:description: Paulo Sérgio Pinheiro, chairman of a United Nations panel investigating human rights abuses in Syria.

item.title: Loved and Hated, Former Premier of Thailand Is Erased From Textbook
item.description: In a plugged-in Thailand, it is unclear to what degree the military junta can remove Thaksin Shinawatra from the public’s consciousness.
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS FULLER
item.media:description: Thaksin Shinawatra in Hong Kong in 2012. He was in power from 2001 to 2006.

item.title: Sweden Looks to Exclude Far Right From Coalition
item.description: The fragmented political mainstream in Sweden scrambled to form a coalition government strong enough to exclude the surging far right.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID CROUCH

item.title: World Briefing: Russia: Putin’s Loyalists Dominate Vote
item.description: Candidates loyal to President Vladimir V. Putin won elections for governor in all 30 regions that held elections on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID M. HERSZENHORN
